thread.title: Earnhardt Jr. on a similar skid this late in the Chase
thread.title_full: Earnhardt Jr. on a similar skid this late in the Chase

title: Earnhardt Jr. on a similar skid this late in the Chase
text:
Hurricane Joachim wreaking havoc on Dover Sprint Cup race KANSAS CITY - 
When Dale Earnhardt Jr. got to Kansas Speedway last October, it was the start of a three-race slide that took the No. 88 Hendrick Motorports Chevrolet team right out of the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship. 
It started with the 39th-place finish at Kansas, followed by a 20th-place finish at Charlotte Motor Speedway and then a disastrous 31st-place result at Talladega. 
This time around, Earnhardt faces a similar skein after his 28th-place finish at Charlotte last week in the Bank of America 500. 
With Jimmie Johnson already eliminated from the Chase in the first round, NASCAR could face a 1-2 blow losing two of its most popular drivers after two rounds of the Chase if Earnhardt does not bounce back big time on Sunday at Kansas in the Hollywood Casino 400. 
Earnhardt goes into Sunday’s race in 11th spot in the Chase standings, 19 points back of the eighth spot currently held Brad Keselowski and the No. 2 Team Penske Ford. 
With four drivers to be eliminated after next week’s race at Talladega Superspeedway, Earnhardt’s position is precarious to say the least. 
The problem is not necessarily just the 19-point deficit to the final Chase spot, it is that there are two other drivers — Ryan Newman in the No. 31 Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet and Kyle Busch in the No. 18 Joe Gibbs Racing Toyota — between Earnhardt and that last transfer position. 
It very well could come down to Earnhardt having to win outright this Sunday at Kansas or next Sunday at Talladega or he will be on the outside looking in for the second year in a row going into the third Chase round. 
Despite the onerous task in front of him, Earnhardt professed this week to be jacked at the chance to indeed move to the next round. 
“You can sit there and put it in a negative light and think about how crappy the position you’re in, but you’re not going to advance with that attitude,” Earnhardt said on his weekly ‘Dale Jr. Download’ podcast. “You’ve got to go in there thinking about the positives and how you’re in a good place. 
“Shake it off, man. One minute spent worrying about what just happened and being negative is one minute wasted. Let’s get after it.” 
NASCAR’s most popular driver, in fact, seems to relish the position the No. 88 team finds itself in, saying he is looking forward to the challenge of getting back in contention for the championship. 
Earnhardt said he figures some of the other drivers in front of him on the points pole may try to just escape damage over the next two races to maintain their spots and that would suit him just fine. 
“These other guys are going to just try to take care of themselves, try to survive,” he said. “A few of us will be out there for blood, trying to claw our way back in. I like being able to race like that. I hate being nervous and worried.” 
Although he has zero wins in 18 starts at the 1.5-mile Kansas oval, Earnhardt has a decent record with three top-five results, including a third-place finish earlier this year and nine top 10 finishes. 
And his fans should not expect him to attempt some form of retaliation against Carl Edwards in the No. 19 JGR Toyota after the pair tangled at Charlotte. 
“A lot of people want me to go wreck Carl,” Earnhardt said. “I’m not going to do that, because if I’m trying to wreck Carl, I’m not winning Kansas, I’m not winning Talladega. 
“You can’t go chase after a guy and put him out of the race and accomplish what your goals are. 
“We’re not going to worry about Carl or start some (crap) show between me and him,” he said. “It’s over and done.” 
What he hopes isn’t over and done is his chance for a first Sprint Cup championship. 
FINISH LINES 
NASCAR has come down hard on Keselowski and the No. 2 Ford team after they accumulated four written warnings for rules infractions. NASCAR ruled that every fourth warning a team received would result in automatic loss of pit selection at the next event and that Keselowski will get last pick at Kansas no matter where the No. 2 team qualifies on Saturday ... Pegged as a future Formula 1 star, 23-year-old Kevin Magnussen has been told he will be out of a job a McLaren/Honda at the end of the 2015 season, according to a report at Autosport.com. 
TRUEX CLOSE BUT NOT QUITE 
KANSAS CITY — Martin Truex is not a prospector, but he does hope to strike gold on Sunday in the Hollywood Casino 400 at Kansas Speedway. 
The driver of the No. 78 Furniture Row Racing Chevrolet nearly won at the 1.5-mile oval twice — finishing second — and was out front at the track in the spring race this season before running out of fuel. 
“Kansas is the race that I keep on saying that we’re due to strike gold,” Truex said this week. “It’s been one of my better tracks over the years with a couple runner-up finishes. 
“I felt we had the car to beat in this year’s spring race — we led the most laps, but fuel-mileage strategy bit us at the end.” 
Truex and his Canadian crew chief Cole Pearn go into Sunday’s race a solid third in the Chase for the Sprint Cup Championship and they hope to build on that this week. 
Certainly a win would propel the team into the next round and avoid the drama that is Talladega next week. 
“A victory at Kansas would mean automatic advancement into the next round of the Chase and no sleepless nights worrying about the wildcard race at Talladega,” Truex said. “There’s something about Kansas Speedway that makes me feel comfortable. 
“Any time you have confidence in a track it’s a huge advantage, especially in high-pressure situations as we are right now in the middle of the Chase.” Sponsored Links
